His early life housing and living conditions would have been comfortable but not luxurious, typical of the middle class of the time. He did not inherit any significant privileges or disadvantages due to his birth.
sources: "Adrian VI | pope." Encyclopedia Britannica, www.britannica.com/biography/Adrian-VI. "Adrian VI." New Catholic Encyclopedia, 2nd ed., vol. 1, Gale, 2003, pp. 125-126.

explanation: Benedetto Marcello was born into a noble family in Venice, Italy. His father, Agostino Marcello, held the position of a senator and his mother was a member of the Loredan family, one of the oldest and most respected families in Venice. The Marcello family was wealthy and influential, providing Benedetto with a privileged upbringing. He had access to education due to his family background, studying law at a young age. His early life housing and living conditions were likely luxurious, fitting for a family of their status in Venetian society.
sources: "Benedetto Marcello: His Life and Works" by Eleanor Selfridge-Field; "The New Grove Dictionary of Music and Musicians" by Stanley Sadie.

explanation: Antonio Fogazzaro was born into a middle-class family in Vicenza, Italy, in 1842. His father, Mariano Fogazzaro, was a notary, a profession that typically belonged to the middle class during this period. His mother, Margherita Lazzari Fogazzaro, came from a family of merchants, another middle-class occupation. The family was well-off enough to provide Antonio with a good education, as he attended a private school in Vicenza before studying law at the University of Padua. This suggests that the family had some wealth and social standing, but not to the extent of the elite class. The family's home and living conditions are not well-documented, but it can be inferred from their occupations and ability to afford a good education for Antonio that they were comfortable. There is no evidence of any inherited privileges or disadvantages.
sources:
- "Antonio Fogazzaro." Encyclopædia Britannica. https://www.britannica.com/biography/Antonio-Fogazzaro
- "Fogazzaro, Antonio." Treccani, the Italian Encyclopedia. http://www.treccani.it/enciclopedia/antonio-fogazzaro_(Dizionario-Biografico)

explanation:
Vittoria Colonna was born into one of the most powerful and wealthy noble families in Italy, the Colonna family. Her father, Fabrizio Colonna, was a grand constable of the Kingdom of Naples, a position of high military rank. Her mother, Agnese da Montefeltro, was the daughter of Federico da Montefeltro, Duke of Urbino, another prominent noble family. The Colonna family had a long history of political influence and military leadership in Rome and Naples, and they owned vast estates across Italy.

Vittoria's birth into the Colonna family would have granted her access to a high level of education, as was typical for children of the nobility during this period. She was known to have been well-educated, suggesting that she had access to tutors and resources due to her family's wealth and status.

Her early life housing and living conditions would have been luxurious, befitting her status as a member of the nobility. She would have grown up in grand palaces and estates, surrounded by servants and luxury.

In terms of inherited privileges, Vittoria would have benefited from her family's wealth, political influence, and social connections. Her noble birth would have granted her a high social status from the moment of her birth.
sources: 1. Robin, Diana Maury, Anne R. Larsen and Carole Levin. "Encyclopedia of Women in the Renaissance: Italy, France

explanation: Baldassare Peruzzi was born in Siena, Italy, in 1481. His father, Matteo Peruzzi, was a modestly successful stonemason, which places the family in the middle class according to the typology provided. Stonemasonry was a skilled craft, and while it did not provide the wealth and prestige of the elite class, it would have provided a comfortable living for the family. The fact that Peruzzi was able to receive an education in drawing and painting suggests that his family had enough resources to afford this, further supporting the classification of middle class. However, there is no evidence to suggest that the Peruzzi family was particularly wealthy or influential in Siena society, and they would not have had the same level of inherited privileges as the elite class.
sources: Vasari, Giorgio. "Lives of the Most Eminent Painters, Sculptors, and Architects." 1550.

explanation: Olaus Magnus was born in Sweden, not Italy, around 1490. He was born into a family of clergy, with his father being a canon at Uppsala Cathedral. His brother, Johannes Magnus, also became a clergyman. This suggests that the family was of the middle class, as clergy often fell into this category during the late 1400s. They would have had some wealth and status, but not to the extent of the elite or nobility. The fact that both Olaus and his brother were able to become educated and join the clergy suggests that their family had the resources to provide them with an education, a privilege often associated with the middle class. However, there is no evidence to suggest that they lived in particularly luxurious conditions or had significant inherited privileges.
sources: "Olaus Magnus: A Description of the Northern Peoples 1555" by Peter Foote, "The History of the Nordic Map: From Prehistory to the Present" by Stefan Brink and Peter Lundén.

explanation: Giovanni Baglione was born in Rome around 1566. His father, Benedetto Baglione, was a notary, a profession that would place the family in the middle class according to the social structure of late 16th century Italy. Notaries were skilled professionals who played a crucial role in the legal and administrative systems of the time. They were not as wealthy as the nobility or the merchant class, but they were certainly above the subsistence level. There is no record of Baglione's mother's occupation, but it is unlikely that she would have worked outside the home given the social norms of the time. Baglione's access to education would have been determined by his family's status. As the son of a notary, he would have had access to a basic education, but not the advanced education reserved for the children of the elite. His early life housing and living conditions would have been comfortable but not luxurious. There is no record of any inherited privileges or disadvantages.
sources: "Giovanni Baglione: A Life in Context" by Maryvelma Smith O'Neil, "The Notaries of Early Modern Rome" by Paul Nelles.

explanation: Giambattista Bodoni was born in Saluzzo, Italy, in 1740. His father, Francesco Agostino Bodoni, was a printer, which suggests that the family belonged to the middle class, as they were involved in a skilled trade. The family was not nobility, nor were they subsistence laborers. The fact that Bodoni later became a famous typographer suggests that he likely had access to some form of education or training in his youth, which would have been more accessible to middle-class families. However, there is no specific information about the family's wealth, housing, or inherited privileges or disadvantages.
sources: "Giambattista Bodoni: His Life and His World" by Valerie Lester; "The Ideal of the Printer: Giambattista Bodoni's Manuale Tipografico" by Moya Jones.

explanation: Pinturicchio, whose real name was Bernardino di Betto, was born in Perugia, Italy, around 1452. His father, Benedetto di Betto, was a craftsman, specifically a shipwright, which suggests a middle-class background. The nickname "Pinturicchio" means "little painter," hinting at an early exposure to the arts, possibly through his family or local community. However, there is no evidence to suggest that his family was particularly wealthy or that he had access to extensive formal education due to his family background. His early life housing and living conditions are not well-documented, but given his father's occupation, it's reasonable to assume they were modest but not impoverished. There is no record of any inherited privileges or disadvantages.
sources: Vasari, Giorgio. "Lives of the Most Eminent Painters Sculptors and Architects." Modern Library, 2006. (Original work published 1550)

explanation: Paolo Sarpi was born in Venice, Italy, in 1552. His father, Francesco Sarpi, was a merchant, which would place the family in the middle class according to the provided typology. His mother, Isabella Morelli, was the sister of a Venetian senator, which suggests some level of political connection but does not necessarily imply elite status. Sarpi's parents died when he was young, and he was raised by his uncle, a modestly wealthy merchant. This suggests that the family had some level of wealth, but not to the extent of the elite class. Sarpi was educated by the Jesuits, which suggests that his family had the resources to provide him with a good education, a privilege often associated with the middle and elite classes. However, it's important to note that his education was likely facilitated by his uncle's connections rather than the family's wealth alone.
sources: "Paolo Sarpi: A Servant of God and State," by David Wootton; "The Life of Paolo Sarpi," by Peter Soave.

explanation: Clément Marot was born in Cahors, France, not Italy, around 1496. His father, Jean Marot, was a well-known poet and his mother, Louise Gaucher, came from a family of artisans. Jean Marot served as a secretary and poet to various members of the French court, including Anne of Brittany, the wife of two successive French kings. This indicates that the Marot family had a certain level of social standing and access to the court, but they were not part of the nobility. Clément Marot's early education likely came from his father, who would have taught him the basics of poetry and literature. The family's living conditions would have been comfortable but not luxurious, fitting for a family of their social standing.
sources: "Clément Marot: A Renaissance Poet Discovers the Gospel" by Francis Higman; "Clément Marot and Religion: A Reassessment in the Light of his Psalm Paraphrases" by Pauline Matarasso.

explanation: Gaspare Spontini was born in Maiolati, Italy, in 1774. His parents were not of the elite class, nor were they subsistence laborers. His father, Giuseppe Spontini, was a shoemaker, a profession that would have placed the family in the middle class according to the social structure of late 18th century Italy. Shoemaking was a skilled craft, and while it did not provide the wealth of the elite, it would have provided a stable income above subsistence level. There is no evidence to suggest that the family was particularly wealthy or impoverished during Spontini's childhood. As for education, Spontini was sent to study at the seminary of Jesi, but it is unclear whether this was due to his family's resources or his own merit. However, the fact that he was able to receive an education suggests at least some level of financial stability in his family.
sources: "Gaspare Spontini" by Friedrich Lippmann, "Gaspare Spontini and His French and German Operas" by Alexander Weatherson.

explanation: Vincenzo Scamozzi was born in Vicenza, Italy, in 1548. His father, Guido Scamozzi, was a surveyor and builder, which would place the family in the middle class according to the typology provided. This profession would have provided a stable income and a certain level of social standing, but not to the extent of the elite class. Vincenzo's access to education was likely due to his father's profession and the family's middle-class status. He was trained by his father in the principles of architecture, a form of education that would have been inaccessible to those in the subsistence class. The family's living conditions would have been comfortable but not lavish, consistent with their middle-class status.
sources: "Vincenzo Scamozzi." Encyclopædia Britannica. Encyclopædia Britannica, inc., 20 July 1998. Web. 20 Sept. 2021.

explanation: Luca Signorelli was born in Cortona, a small town in Tuscany, Italy. His family was not of noble birth, but they were not poor either. His father, Egidio Signorelli, was a well-respected local man who held a position in the local government. This suggests that the family had a certain level of wealth and social standing, but they were not part of the elite ruling class. The fact that Signorelli was able to receive an education and train as a painter also suggests that his family had enough resources to support his studies, which was not common for families of lower social classes at the time. However, there is no evidence to suggest that Signorelli's family was exceptionally wealthy or that he inherited any significant privileges or advantages.
sources: Vasari, Giorgio. "Lives of the Most Eminent Painters Sculptors and Architects." 1550.

explanation: Sebastiano del Piombo, originally named Sebastiano Luciani, was born in Venice, Italy, around 1485. His father, Giovanni Luciani, was a respectable notary, a profession that would have placed the family in the middle class of the social structure of the time. The notarial profession required a level of education and literacy, suggesting that the family had access to some form of education. However, there is no evidence to suggest that they were part of the elite or nobility, nor that they lived in poverty or subsistence conditions. The family's exact wealth is not well-documented, but the notarial profession was generally associated with a comfortable, though not extravagant, lifestyle. Sebastiano's early life housing and living conditions, as well as any inherited privileges or disadvantages, are not well-documented in historical sources.
sources: "Sebastiano del Piombo: A Life in Painting" by Michael Hirst, "The Renaissance in Venice" by Peter Humfrey.

explanation: Giovanni Paolo Panini was born in Piacenza, Italy, around 1691. His family background is not extensively documented, but it is known that he received education in the humanities and arts from an early age, suggesting a middle-class background. His family likely had enough resources to provide him with a good education, which was not a common privilege for the lower classes in late 17th-century Italy. This indicates that his family was probably part of the middle class, which included merchants, artisans, skilled craftspeople, and teachers. However, there is no evidence to suggest that his family was part of the elite or ruling class, nor that they were subsistence-level laborers or peasants.
sources: "Giovanni Paolo Panini," Encyclopædia Britannica, https://www.britannica.com/biography/Giovanni-Paolo-Panini.

explanation: Ascanio Condivi was born in Ripatransone, in the Marche region of Italy. His father was a notary, a profession that required literacy and a certain level of education, suggesting that the family was part of the middle class. Notaries were important figures in the local community, often dealing with legal matters and contracts, which further supports the idea that Condivi's family was not subsistence level. However, there is no evidence to suggest that his family was part of the elite or nobility. The fact that Condivi later went on to study at the University of Bologna also suggests that his family had the means to support his education, a privilege not available to all during this period.
sources: "Life of Michelangelo" by Ascanio Condivi, "The Lives of the Artists" by Giorgio Vasari, "Ascanio Condivi, Michelangelo, and the Sistine Chapel: A Study of Condivi’s Life of Michelangelo in Relation to the Iconography of the Sistine Chapel" by Charles de Tolnay.

explanation: Francesco Granacci was born in Florence, Italy, around 1469. His family background is not extensively documented, but it is known that he was apprenticed to the painter Domenico Ghirlandaio. This suggests that his family had enough resources to arrange and possibly pay for an apprenticeship, a common practice among the middle class during this period. Apprenticeships were often arranged by families who were artisans themselves or had connections in the artisan community. However, there's no evidence to suggest that Granacci's family belonged to the elite class of Florence, such as the Medici family, or that they were subsistence-level laborers or peasants. The fact that Granacci was able to receive training as a painter from a young age also indicates that his family had some means and valued education, another characteristic of the middle class during this period.
sources: Vasari, Giorgio. "Lives of the Most Eminent Painters Sculptors and Architects." Modern Library, 2006.

explanation: Giovanni Giacomo de Rossi was born into a family of printers and publishers, a profession that would place them in the middle class according to the specified typology. His father, Giuseppe de Rossi, was the founder of the family publishing business, which was one of the leading publishers in Rome during the 17th century. The family business indicates a level of wealth and stability, but not to the extent of the elite class. The profession of printer and publisher would have required a certain level of education, suggesting that the family had access to educational resources. explanation: Raffaello Maffei was born into a prominent and wealthy family in Volterra, Italy. The Maffei family was part of the ruling class in Volterra and had a long history of involvement in the city's political and social affairs. Raffaello's early life would have been characterized by a high level of comfort and privilege, with access to education and other opportunities that were typically reserved for the elite. explanation: Giovanni Antonio Amadeo was born in Pavia, Italy, around 1447. His father, Antonio Maria, was a stonemason, which was a skilled craft occupation. explanation: Jacob Obrecht was born in Ghent, which is now part of Belgium, not Italy, around 1457. His father, Willem Obrecht, was a well-known city trumpeter, a position that would have placed the family in the middle class. This occupation would have provided a stable income and some degree of prestige within the community. Jacob's mother died in 1460 when he was just three years old, and his father remarried a year later. There's no evidence to suggest that the family was particularly wealthy, but they would have been comfortable. Jacob's father's position would have given him access to education, and indeed, he was educated at the Latin school in Ghent. His early life housing and living conditions would have been typical of a middle-class family in Ghent at the time.
sources: "Jacob Obrecht: A Flemish Composer of the Renaissance" by Rob C. Wegman, "The New Grove Dictionary of Music and Musicians" edited by Stanley Sadie and John Tyrrell.

explanation: Annio da Viterbo, also known as Giovanni Nanni, was born in Viterbo, Italy, around 1432. His father, Pietro Nanni, was a physician, a profession that would have placed the family in the middle class during the late Middle Ages. The family likely had some wealth, as evidenced by Annio's education. He entered the Dominican Order at an early age, where he would have received a religious and scholarly education. This suggests that his family had the means to provide him with an education, a privilege not available to all during this time period. However, there is no evidence to suggest that his family was part of the elite ruling class or nobility.

explanation: Juan Andrés was born into a middle-class family in the Kingdom of Naples, which is now part of Italy. The fact that his father was a lawyer indicates that the family had access to education, as this profession required a certain level of formal training. explanation: Ottaviano Petrucci was born in Fossombrone, Italy, around 1466. His father, Pietro Petrucci, was a public official, serving as a tax collector, which suggests a middle-class status. The family was not of noble lineage, but they were not impoverished either. They had enough resources to provide Ottaviano with an education, as he studied law at the University of Padua, a privilege not typically accessible to the lower classes during this period. However, there is no evidence to suggest that the family was particularly wealthy or that they lived in luxurious conditions. Therefore, based on the occupation of his father and his access to education, it can be inferred that Ottaviano Petrucci was born into a middle-class family.

explanation: Frederic William Henry Myers was born into a wealthy family. His father, Revd Frederic Myers, was a clergyman and a school inspector, which indicates a high social standing. His mother, Susan Harriet Myers, was the daughter of a wealthy merchant, further indicating their elite status. The family's wealth allowed Myers to receive a high-quality education, as he attended Cheltenham College and later Trinity College, Cambridge. This level of education was typically only accessible to the elite class during this time period. The family's housing and living conditions are not well-documented, but given their wealth and social standing, it is likely they were comfortable. Myers did not face any known inherited disadvantages.

explanation: Carlo Matteucci was born on June 20, 1811, in Forlì, a city in the region of Emilia-Romagna, Italy. explanation: John de Lugo was born into a noble family in Spain, not Italy, around 1583. His father, Don Juan de Lugo y de Quiroga, was a knight of the Order of Santiago and a high-ranking official in the Spanish government, serving as the governor of the province of Galicia. This suggests that the family was of high social standing and wealth at the time of John's birth and childhood. The fact that John was able to study at the University of Salamanca, one of the most prestigious educational institutions in Spain at the time, also indicates that his family had the means to provide him with a high-quality education. As a member of the nobility, John would have been born with certain privileges, such as access to education and opportunities for advancement in society.

explanation: Peter Faber, also known as Pierre Favre, was born in 1506 in Villaret, Savoy in the French Alps, not Italy. His family was of modest means, and his parents were shepherds. explanation: Francesco Barozzi was born into a noble family in Venice, Italy. They were part of the Venetian patriciate, the ruling class of Venice, which was a republic at the time. The Barozzi family had produced several Doges (the highest political office in Venice) and other high-ranking officials. Francesco's father, Jacopo Barozzi, was a nobleman, and his mother, Elena Morosini, came from another noble Venetian family. The Barozzi family was wealthy, owning several properties in Venice and its territories. Francesco would have had access to education due to his family's status and wealth. He lived in a noble household, likely in a palazzo, a type of grand residence typical of Venetian nobility.
sources:

sources: "Aonio Paleario and his Friends" by Frederic Christie, "The Italian Reformation: A History of the Growth of Evangelical Religion in Italy, from 1300 to 1564" by Thomas McCrie.

explanation: Felice Cavallotti was born in Milan, Italy, on December 6, 1842. His father, Giuseppe Cavallotti, was a lawyer by profession, which suggests that the family was of the middle class, as law was a profession typically pursued by those with some level of education and financial stability. There is no evidence to suggest that the Cavallotti family was part of the elite aristocracy or nobility, nor that they were subsistence-level laborers or peasants. The fact that Felice Cavallotti was able to pursue education in law at the University of Pavia also suggests a certain level of family wealth and access to education, which would be consistent with a middle-class upbringing. However, specific details about the family's wealth, living conditions, or inherited privileges or disadvantages are not readily available.
sources: "Felice Cavallotti: Italian Patriot and Dramatist" by William A. Drake (1920); "Cavallotti, Felice" in the Dizionario Biografico degli Italiani - Volume 23 (1979).

explanation: Giuseppe Gazzaniga was born in Verona, Italy, in 1743. His father, Felice Gazzaniga, was a professional violinist, which suggests that the family was not of the subsistence class, as Felice had a specialized skill. However, there is no evidence to suggest that the family was part of the elite class either. The fact that Giuseppe was able to receive a musical education from a young age, studying under the guidance of Niccolò Jommelli and Giovanni Battista Martini, indicates that his family had enough resources to provide him with this opportunity. This suggests that the Gazzaniga family was likely part of the middle class, as they had access to education and a certain level of financial stability, but were not part of the ruling elite.
sources: "Giuseppe Gazzaniga: His Life and Music" by John A. Rice, "The New Grove Dictionary of Music and Musicians" edited by Stanley Sadie and John Tyrrell.

explanation: Giacomo Ceruti, also known as Pitocchetto, was born in Lombardy, Italy around 1698. His father was a painter, which suggests a middle-class background as painting was considered a skilled craft during this period. There is no evidence to suggest that his family was particularly wealthy or impoverished, so it is reasonable to assume that they were of average means for their social class. The fact that Ceruti became a painter suggests that he likely received some form of education or training in his youth, which would have been more accessible to middle-class families. However, there is no specific information available about his early life housing, living conditions, or inherited privileges or disadvantages.
sources: "Giacomo Ceruti" by Roberto Longhi, published in "Paragone" (1953); "Giacomo Ceruti and the 'Scuola Lombarda'" by Ferdinando Arisi, published in "Bollettino d'Arte" (1962).

explanation: Luigi Palma di Cesnola was born into a noble family in Rivarolo Canavese, in the Kingdom of Sardinia (now Italy). His father, Count Michele Palma di Cesnola, was a member of the aristocracy, indicating a high social standing and likely access to wealth and resources. This would have provided Luigi with a privileged upbringing, including access to education and comfortable living conditions. As a member of the nobility, Luigi would have also inherited certain privileges, such as social connections and potential political influence.
sources: "The Life of General Louis Palma Di Cesnola," by Henry S. Olcott (1886); "The Palma di Cesnola Collection in the Stanford University Museum," by A.D. Fraser (1940).

explanation: Jacopo Ferretti was born in Rome, Italy, in 1784. His father, Giuseppe Ferretti, was a servant for a noble family, the Chigi family. This position, while not making the family wealthy, would have provided a stable income and a certain level of social standing. The Ferretti family would have had access to the Chigi family's resources, including their library, which would have provided Jacopo with an education beyond what was typical for his social class. However, the family was not part of the ruling class or nobility, and their wealth and social standing were dependent on their employment with the Chigi family. Therefore, Jacopo Ferretti's birth and childhood social class can be classified as middle class.
sources: "Jacopo Ferretti, librettist: a survey of his life and works" by Roberta Montemorra Marvin, "The Chigi Family and their Servants: Patronage, Politics and the Household in Early Modern Rome" by John A. Marino.

explanation: Benedict Pereira, also known as Pererius, was born in Ruzafa, near Valencia, Spain, not Italy, around 1535. His family was of Jewish descent, but they had converted to Christianity, a common practice at the time due to the pressures of the Spanish Inquisition. His father was a merchant, which places them in the middle class according to the given typology. There is no evidence to suggest that his family was particularly wealthy or impoverished. His access to education was likely due to his family's conversion to Christianity and their middle-class status, as education in that era was often tied to religious institutions and was more accessible to those of certain social standings. There is no specific information available about his early life housing and living conditions, but as the son of a merchant, it can be inferred that they were likely adequate for the period. As a converso (a Jew who had converted to Christianity), Pereira would have faced certain social disadvantages, but his family's conversion also would have opened up opportunities not available to practicing Jews.
sources: "Benedict Pereira (Pererius): His Life, Thought, and Influence" by John P. Doyle; "The Spanish Inquisition: A Historical Revision" by Henry Kamen.

explanation:
Lawrence Giustiniani, also known as Lorenzo Giustiniani, was born into the prominent and wealthy Giustiniani family in Venice, Italy around 1381. The Giustiniani family was part of the Venetian patriciate, the ruling class of the Republic of Venice, which was composed of wealthy aristocratic families. The family had a long history of producing Doges, the elected leaders of Venice, indicating their high social standing and political influence. 

At the time of Lawrence's birth, the family was involved in trade, banking, and politics, which were typical occupations of the Venetian elite. The family's wealth would have ensured Lawrence access to education, a privilege not available to all in the late 1300s. The Giustiniani family also owned several palaces in Venice, suggesting that Lawrence's early life housing and living conditions were of a high standard.
sources:
1. Madden, Thomas F. "Venice: A New History." Penguin Books, 2013.
2. Norwich, John Julius. "A History of Venice." Vintage Books, 1989.
3. Lane, Frederic Chapin. "Venice, A Maritime Republic." Johns Hopkins University Press, 1973.

explanation: Costantino Nigra was born on June 11, 1828, in Fubine, Piedmont, a region in Northern Italy. His father, Giuseppe Nigra, was a notary, a profession that required literacy, legal knowledge, and a certain level of social standing. This suggests that the Nigra family was part of the middle class, as notaries typically served as intermediaries between the elite and the lower classes, handling legal matters such as contracts, wills, and property transactions. There is no evidence to suggest that the Nigra family was part of the elite or subsistence classes. Costantino Nigra's access to education was likely due to his family's middle-class status, as his father's profession would have valued and promoted literacy and learning. However, specific details about his early life housing and living conditions, family wealth, and inherited privileges or disadvantages are not readily available.
sources: "Costantino Nigra: Un diplomatico piemontese nell'Europa del Risorgimento" by Roberto G. Salvadori, "Dizionario Biografico degli Italiani" by Treccani.

explanation: Matteo Palmieri was born in Florence, Italy around 1406. His family belonged to the middle class, specifically the artisan class. His father was a pharmacist, a profession that required skill and knowledge, placing them in the middle class of the social hierarchy. This class was characterized by merchants, artisans, skilled craftspeople, and teachers. Palmieri's family was not part of the ruling elite or nobility, but they were also not subsistence-level laborers or peasants. His access to education was likely due to his family's middle-class status, as education during this period was not universally accessible and was often tied to social standing. The family's wealth and living conditions are not well-documented, but as a pharmacist, his father would have had a steady income, suggesting a comfortable living situation for the time.
sources: "Matteo Palmieri, 1406-1475, and his Material Fortune," by Francis William Kent, in "Rinascimento," Vol. 22 (1982), pp. 3-36; "The World of the Early Renaissance," by Paul Oskar Kristeller.

explanation: Leonardo Salviati was born into the Salviati family, one of the most influential and wealthy families in Florence, Italy during the Renaissance period. His father, Jacopo Salviati, was a prominent banker and politician, and his mother, Lucrezia di Lorenzo de' Medici, was a member of the powerful Medici family, which ruled Florence for much of the Renaissance period. The Salviati family was part of the ruling class and nobility, with significant wealth and political influence. Leonardo would have had access to education and other opportunities due to his family's status and wealth. His early life housing and living conditions would have been of a high standard, befitting his family's status. He would have inherited significant privileges due to his birth into the Salviati family.
sources: "The Salviati Family in the Florentine Renaissance: A Social and Cultural History" by Caroline P. Murphy; "The Medici: Power, Money, and Ambition in the Italian Renaissance" by Paul Strathern.

explanation: Agostinho Barbosa was born in Portugal, not Italy, around 1589. His father, Manuel Barbosa, was a notary, a profession that would place the family in the middle class according to the social structure of the time. This occupation would have provided a stable income and a certain level of social standing, but would not have placed them among the elite or nobility. The fact that Agostinho Barbosa was able to study law at the University of Coimbra suggests that his family had enough resources to afford a good education, a privilege typically associated with the middle class. However, there is no evidence to suggest that the Barbosa family was particularly wealthy or that they lived in luxurious conditions.
sources: "Agostinho Barbosa: His Life and Work" by José Domingues in the Journal of the History of International Law (2006); "The Portuguese Jurist Agostinho Barbosa (1589-1649)" by A. H. de Oliveira Marques in the Bulletin of Hispanic Studies (1964).

explanation: Tullia d'Aragona was born into a family of high social standing. Her father, Cardinal Luigi d'Aragona, was a member of the Italian nobility and a high-ranking church official. Her mother, Giulia Ferrarese, was a courtesan, a position that, while stigmatized, was often held by educated and cultured women who had access to the upper echelons of society. Tullia's birth to a noble father and a courtesan mother placed her in a unique social position, with access to the privileges of the elite class, including education, wealth, and connections to powerful individuals. However, her illegitimate birth and her mother's profession may have also brought certain social disadvantages. Nevertheless, considering the social structure and economic context of Italy in the late 1500s, Tullia d'Aragona would be classified as part of the elite class.
sources: "Tullia d'Aragona." Encyclopedia of Italian Literary Studies, edited by Gaetana Marrone, Routledge, 2007. "Tullia d'Aragona and the 'Dialogo della Infinità d'Amore.'" The Italianist, vol. 10, 1990, pp. 5-25.

explanation: Nicola Salvi was born in Rome around 1697. His father, Pietro Salvi, was a well-established lawyer, which suggests that the family belonged to the middle class. The profession of law was typically associated with the middle class during this period in Italy, as it required a level of education and literacy not commonly accessible to the lower classes. While there is little specific information about Salvi's early life, his father's profession suggests that the family had a reasonable level of wealth and that Salvi likely had access to education. However, there is no evidence to suggest that the family was part of the elite or ruling class, nor that they were struggling for subsistence.
sources: The primary source of information about Salvi's early life is the biography written by his contemporary, the art historian Luigi Crespi. Crespi's "Vita di Nicola Salvi" provides details about Salvi's family background and early life. Further information can be found in various scholarly works on the history of Rome and Italy in the late 17th and early 18th centuries.

explanation: Gherardo Starnina was born in Florence, Italy, around 1354. However, considering the social structure and economic context of Florence in the late 14th century, it is reasonable to infer that Starnina was born into a middle-class family. Florence was a thriving center of commerce and art during this period, and the middle class, composed of merchants, artisans, and skilled craftspeople, was particularly prominent. Starnina's later career as a painter suggests that he likely came from an artisanal background, as the skills and training required for this profession were typically passed down through families and apprenticeships, which were accessible primarily to those in the middle class. It is also worth noting that access to education in this period was largely determined by social class, and Starnina's ability to read and write, as evidenced by his signed works, suggests that he likely had some form of education, further supporting the inference that he came from a middle-class background.

However, general historical studies of Florence during this period, such as Richard Goldthwaite's "The Economy of Renaissance Florence" and John Najemy's "A History of Florence

explanation: Mondino de Liuzzi, also known as Mundinus, was born in Bologna, Italy, around 1275. His father was a physician, which suggests that the family belonged to the middle class, as this profession required a certain level of education and skill. This is further supported by the fact that Mondino was able to attend the University of Bologna, one of the most prestigious universities of the time, which would have been difficult without some level of family wealth or social standing. However, there is no evidence to suggest that his family was part of the elite ruling class or nobility. explanation: Francesco Brizio was born in Bologna, Italy around 1574. His father, Giovanni Battista Brizio, was a goldsmith, which was a skilled craft occupation. This suggests that the family was likely part of the middle class, as they were not nobility but had a trade that required skill and could provide a reasonable income. There is no evidence to suggest that the family was particularly wealthy or impoverished. The fact that Brizio later became a painter suggests that he may have had some access to education or training in the arts, which would have been more likely if his family had some means. However, there is no specific evidence about his early life housing, living conditions, or any inherited privileges or disadvantages.

explanation: Angelo Anelli was born in Desenzano del Garda, Italy, in 1761. His family was of the middle class, with his father being a physician. This would have provided the family with a stable income and a certain level of social standing within their community. The fact that Anelli was able to study at the University of Pavia, where he graduated in law, suggests that his family had the financial means to support his education. However, there is no evidence to suggest that his family was part of the elite ruling class or nobility, nor that they were subsistence-level laborers or peasants.
sources: "Angelo Anelli, librettista di Rossini e Donizetti" by Alessandro Roccatagliati; "Angelo Anelli e il melodramma italiano nel primo Ottocento" by Maria Rosa De Luca.

explanation: Alessandro Striggio was born into a noble family in Mantua, Italy, around 1540. His father, also named Alessandro Striggio, was a prominent diplomat and courtier in the service of the Gonzaga family, who were the ruling dukes of Mantua. This suggests that the Striggio family had a high social standing and were part of the elite class. The family's wealth and status would have provided young Alessandro with access to a good education and comfortable living conditions. As a member of the nobility, he would have also inherited certain privileges, such as the right to bear a coat of arms and the expectation of a career at court or in the church.
sources: "Alessandro Striggio" in Grove Music Online; "The Courtier and the Madrigal" by Anthony Newcomb; "Music in Renaissance Mantua" by Donald Jay Grout.

explanation: Carlo Dossi, born as Carlo Alberto Pisani Dossi, was born into a noble family in the Kingdom of Lombardy-Venetia, which was then part of the Austrian Empire and is now part of Italy. His father, Count Luigi Pisani Dossi, was a nobleman, indicating that the family belonged to the ruling class or nobility. The family's noble status would have provided them with wealth and access to resources, including education. Dossi himself was educated at the University of Pavia, a privilege that would have been inaccessible to those of lower social classes at the time. His early life housing and living conditions would have been comfortable, reflecting the family's wealth and status. As a member of the nobility, Dossi would have inherited certain privileges, including social standing and access to resources.
sources: "Carlo Dossi: A Reassessment" by John Butcher; "The Italian Tradition of 'Economic Thought'" by Riccardo Faucci, Sergio Marchionatti, and Eleonora Sanfilippo; "The Cambridge Companion to Modern Italian Culture" by Zygmunt G. Barański and Rebecca J. West.

explanation: Giovanni Maria Nanino was born in Tivoli, near Rome, around 1544. His family was not of noble or aristocratic origin, but they were not subsistence level either. His father, Valentino Nanino, was a musician and singer, which suggests a middle-class background. The fact that Giovanni and his brother, Giovanni Bernardino, were able to receive a good education in music from an early age indicates that their family had some means and valued education, which is characteristic of the middle class. However, there is no evidence to suggest that they were particularly wealthy or had any inherited privileges.
sources: "Giovanni Maria Nanino: Life and Works" by Richard Sherr, "Giovanni Maria Nanino (1543/44-1607): Life, Works, Influence" by Anthony Newcomb.

explanation: Dino Compagni was born into a family of the Florentine middle class. His family was involved in the wool trade, a common occupation among the middle class during this period in Italy. The Compagni family was not part of the ruling elite or nobility, but they were also not subsistence-level laborers or peasants. The family's involvement in trade suggests they had some level of wealth and stability, but not to the extent of the aristocracy. Dino's access to education, as evidenced by his later writings, suggests that his family had the resources to provide him with a basic education, a privilege not available to all in this period. However, this is not a direct reflection of his family's wealth or social standing, but rather a common practice among the middle class in Italy at the time.
sources: "Dino Compagni's Chronicle of Florence" by Dino Compagni, "The World of the Florentine Renaissance Artist: Projects and Patrons, Workshop and Art Market" by Martin Wackernagel.

explanation: The birth circumstances and family background of Giuseppe Maria Orlandini, born around 1676, are not well-documented. While it is known that he was born in Florence, Italy, there is little to no information available about his parents, their occupations, or their social standing. Similarly, there is no information about the family's wealth at the time of Orlandini's birth and childhood, his access to education due to his family background, his early life housing and living conditions, or any inherited privileges or disadvantages. However, these records are not readily available or have not been digitized for online access. Further research in Italian archives or libraries may yield more information.

explanation: Enrico Panzacchi was born in Bologna, Italy, on 20 November 1840. His father, Luigi Panzacchi, was a lawyer, and his mother, Teresa Fantuzzi, was a housewife. The profession of his father suggests that the Panzacchi family belonged to the middle class, as lawyers were typically part of the professional class in 19th-century Italy. There is no evidence to suggest that the Panzacchi family was particularly wealthy or impoverished, so it is reasonable to assume that they were of average means for their social class. Enrico Panzacchi was able to attend the University of Bologna, which suggests that his family had enough resources to provide him with a good education. However, this does not necessarily mean that they were wealthy, as education was highly valued in middle-class families and many would have made sacrifices to ensure their children could attend university.
sources: "Enrico Panzacchi" by Giuseppe Antonelli, published in 1904; "The Italian Middle Class: Lawyers, Notaries and the Making of a Political Class in Italy, 1861-1914" by John A. Davis, published in 2013.

explanation: Giuseppe Bazzani was born in Mantua, Italy around 1690. His father, Carlo Bazzani, was a painter and his mother, Lucia, was a homemaker. This suggests that the Bazzani family belonged to the middle class, as Carlo's occupation as a painter indicates a skilled craft. There is no evidence to suggest that the Bazzani family was particularly wealthy or impoverished, which further supports the classification of middle class. The fact that Giuseppe Bazzani was able to become a painter himself suggests that he had access to some form of education or training, likely due to his father's profession. However, there is no evidence to suggest that this education was extensive or elite. The Bazzani family likely lived in modest housing conditions typical of middle class families in late 17th century Italy.
sources: "Giuseppe Bazzani and the Baroque in Lombardy" by Mina Gregori, "The Age of Correggio and the Carracci: Emilian Painting of the 16th and 17th Centuries" by National Gallery of Art (U.S.), Pinacoteca Nazionale di Bologna, Metropolitan Museum of Art (New York, N.Y.)

explanation: Vannoccio Biringuccio was born into a noble family in Siena, Italy. His father, Paolo Biringuccio, was a civil servant who held several public offices, including that of senator and ambassador, which indicates a high social standing. The Biringuccio family was part of the Sienese patriciate, a small group of families who controlled the city's government and economy. This would have provided Vannoccio with a privileged upbringing, including access to education and comfortable living conditions. However, specific details about the family's wealth or the exact nature of their living conditions are not readily available.
sources: "Vannoccio Biringuccio," in Complete Dictionary of Scientific Biography, vol. 2 (Detroit: Charles Scribner's Sons, 2008), 142-144.

explanation: Giorgio Valla was born in Piacenza, Italy, around 1447. His father, Pietro Valla, was a physician, which was a respected profession in the 15th century Italy. This suggests that the family was likely part of the middle class, as physicians were typically well-educated and had a higher social standing than laborers or peasants, but they were not part of the nobility or ruling class. The fact that Giorgio Valla was able to receive an education also suggests that his family had some means, as education was not universally accessible at this time and was often a privilege of the middle and upper classes. However, there is no evidence to suggest that the Valla family was particularly wealthy or that they were part of the elite class.
sources: "Giorgio Valla." The Galileo Project, Rice University. "Physicians in the Middle Ages." The Middle Ages, University of Michigan.

explanation: Carlo Cesare Malvasia was born into a noble family in Bologna, Italy, around 1616. His family was part of the aristocracy, indicating a high social standing and wealth at the time of his birth and throughout his childhood. The Malvasia family was known for their involvement in politics and the church, which further supports their elite status. Carlo's access to education was likely due to his family's status and wealth, as education during this time was often reserved for the elite. His early life housing and living conditions would have been comfortable, given his family's wealth and status. As a member of the aristocracy, Carlo would have inherited certain privileges, such as access to education and a comfortable lifestyle.
sources: "Felsina Pittrice: The Lives of the Bolognese Painters" by Carlo Cesare Malvasia; "Carlo Cesare Malvasia's Felsina Pittrice and Its General Index" by Elizabeth Cropper and Lorenzo Pericolo; "The Social World of the Florentine Humanists, 1390-1460" by Lauro Martines.

explanation: Malwida Freiin von Meysenbug was born into a family of German nobility. Her father, Carl Rivalier, was ennobled in 1815 and given the title of Baron von Meysenbug. The family was part of the ruling class, with her father serving as the Hessian Minister of State. This position would have provided the family with a significant amount of wealth and influence. As a result of her family's status, Malwida would have had access to a high level of education, which was typically reserved for the elite class during this time period. The family's housing and living conditions would have been of a high standard, reflective of their social standing.
sources:
- "Memoirs of an Idealist" by Malwida von Meysenbug
- "Malwida von Meysenbug: A Cosmopolitan in the Age of Nationalism" by Robert Brown
- "The German Bourgeoisie: Essays on the Social History of the German Middle Class from the Late Eighteenth to the Early Twentieth Century" by David Blackbourn and Richard J. Evans.

explanation: Giovanni Battista Coriolano was born into a family of engravers, which was a skilled craft during the late 1500s in Italy. His father, Cristoforo Coriolano, was a well-known engraver from Germany who had moved to Italy. This suggests that the family had a certain level of financial stability and social standing, as engraving was a respected craft. However, there is no information available about their early life housing and living conditions or any inherited privileges or disadvantages.

explanation: Michael Tarchaniota Marullus was born in Constantinople to a Greek family. The family was forced to flee Constantinople when it fell to the Ottoman Turks in 1453, which suggests they were not among the ruling elite. However, Marullus was able to receive an education, suggesting his family had some means. His education was likely due to his family's status as part of the middle class, as education during this time was not typically accessible to those in the subsistence class.

explanation: Isidoro Del Lungo was born in Florence, Italy, in 1841. explanation: Federiko Benković, also known as Federico Bencovich, was born in the city of Split, which was part of the Republic of Venice during the late 1600s. explanation: Carlo Porta was born in Milan, Italy, in 1775. His father, Giuseppe Porta, was a businessman, which suggests that the family was part of the middle class. explanation: Francesco Maria Molza was born into a noble family in Modena, Italy, around 1489. His father, Pietro Maria Molza, was a nobleman and a member of the ruling class in Modena. explanation: Carlo Fea was born in Pigna, Italy, in 1753. His family was of moderate means, and his father was a notary, a profession that typically belonged to the middle class in the 18th century Italy. explanation: Giovanni della Robbia was born into a family of artisans, specifically, a family of renowned sculptors and ceramists. Antonio's early life would have been characterized by the privileges of the nobility, including a high standard of living and access to education. His family's wealth and status would have provided him with opportunities not available to those of lower social classes.

This is further supported by the fact that Elijah received a good education, studying both Jewish and secular subjects, which suggests that his family had the means to provide him with such an education. However, there is no evidence to suggest that they were part of the elite or ruling class, nor that they were living in subsistence conditions.
sources: "Elijah Benamozegh: Israel and Humanity" by Maxwell Luria.

explanation: Pietro Blaserna was born in Rome in 1836. His father, Giuseppe Blaserna, was a lawyer, which suggests a middle-class background. The legal profession was a respected occupation in Italy during the 19th century, often associated with the middle class. There is no evidence to suggest that the Blaserna family was part of the elite aristocracy or nobility, nor that they were subsistence-level laborers or peasants. The fact that Pietro Blaserna was able to attend the University of Rome for his education suggests that his family had sufficient resources to support his studies, which is another indication of a middle-class background. However, there is no specific information available about the family's wealth, living conditions, or inherited privileges or disadvantages.
sources: "Pietro Blaserna." The Catholic Encyclopedia. Vol. 2. New York: Robert Appleton Company, 1907. 15 Dec. 2021 <http://www.newadvent.org/cathen/02584a.htm>.

explanation: Tommaso Piroli was born in Rome, Italy, around 1752. His father, Giovanni Piroli, was a goldsmith, a trade that would have placed the family in the middle class according to the social structure of late 18th-century Italy. Goldsmithing was a skilled craft, and those who practiced it were typically considered artisans, a group that fell within the middle class. There is no evidence to suggest that the Piroli family was particularly wealthy or impoverished, so it is reasonable to assume that they were of average means for their social class. Unfortunately, there is little information available about Piroli's early life, including his access to education, living conditions, or any inherited privileges or disadvantages. However, given his father's occupation, it is likely that Piroli would have had some access to education and a relatively stable upbringing.
sources: The primary source for this information is the "Dizionario Biografico degli Italiani" (Biographical Dictionary of Italians), which includes an entry on Tommaso Piroli. Other potential sources of information could include local records from Rome in the late 18th century, such as baptismal or marriage records, which might provide further insight into the Piroli family's social standing.

explanation: Gaspare Traversi was born in Naples, Italy, around 1722. However, there is no evidence to suggest that his family was particularly wealthy or that they were part of the nobility. explanation: Aleksander Gierymski was born in Warsaw, Poland, not Italy, in 1850. His father, Michał Gierymski, was a civil servant, and his mother, Laura née Mondan, came from a French family that had settled in Poland. His family was not of noble or aristocratic origin, but they were not poor either. His father's occupation as a civil servant would have provided a stable income and a comfortable lifestyle, typical of the middle class. Aleksander also had access to education, as he and his brother Maksymilian, who also became a painter, both studied at the Warsaw School of Fine Arts. This suggests that their family had enough resources to support their education, which was not a privilege accessible to everyone at that time. The family's ability to support Aleksander's education and his father's occupation suggest a middle-class background.
sources: "Aleksander Gierymski." Culture.pl, Adam Mickiewicz Institute. "Aleksander Gierymski." In: Słownik Biograficzny Królestwa Polskiego, vol. II, 1879.

explanation: Vittorino da Feltre was born in Feltre, a small town in the Veneto region of Italy, around 1378. His original name was Vittorino Ramboldini. His father, Costante Ramboldini, was a notary, which was a respected profession in the middle class during the late 1300s. This profession would have provided a stable income for the family, but not to the extent of the wealth associated with the elite class. Vittorino's access to education was likely due to his father's profession and the value placed on literacy and learning in this role. There is no evidence to suggest that Vittorino was born into poverty or that his family struggled to provide for their basic needs, which would be characteristic of the subsistence class. However, there is also no evidence to suggest that he was born into a family of significant wealth or nobility, which would be characteristic of the elite class.
sources: "Vittorino da Feltre and Other Humanist Educators" by William Harrison Woodward, "The Civilization of the Renaissance in Italy" by Jacob Burckhardt.

explanation: Girolamo Mazzola Bedoli was born in Parma, Italy, around 1500 into a family of artisans. This was not a privilege available to those of lower social classes. However, there is no evidence to suggest that the family was particularly wealthy or influential, which would have placed them in the elite class.

explanation: Janus Parrhasius, also known as Giovanni Parrasio, was born in the city of Urbino, Italy, around 1471. explanation: Cesare Dandini was born into a family of artists in Florence, Italy, around 1596. explanation: Enrico Hillyer Giglioli was born in London, England, in 1845 to Italian parents. His father, Giuseppe Giglioli, was a well-known opera singer, which suggests a middle-class background. The profession of opera singer during the 19th century was often associated with a certain level of social standing and financial stability, although it was not equivalent to the wealth and influence of the elite class. The family's ability to travel between England and Italy also suggests a degree of financial means. Enrico received a good education, studying natural sciences in Florence, which further indicates a middle-class upbringing, as access to education was often limited to those with financial resources during this period. However, there is no evidence to suggest that Giglioli was born into the elite class, as there are no records of significant inherited wealth or noble lineage.
sources: "Enrico Hillyer Giglioli, 1845-1909" by P. J. H. Greenwood (1970), "The Italian Community in London: A Case Study of Middle-Class Migration, 1870-1914" by Lucio Sponza (1988).

explanation: Orest Kiprensky was born in the village of Koporye near Saint Petersburg, Russia (not Italy) in 1782. He was the illegitimate son of a landowner named Alexey Dyakonov and his housemaid. As a result of his illegitimate birth, Kiprensky did not have the same privileges as children born into the elite or middle class. He was raised in the house of Adam Shvalber, a serf that had bought his own freedom and worked as a custodian in the Academy of Arts in Saint Petersburg. This suggests that Kiprensky's early life housing and living conditions were likely modest at best. His access to education was not due to his family background, but rather the charity of others. He was admitted to the Academy of Arts in Saint Petersburg as a "volunteer" in 1788, where he began his formal education.
sources: "Orest Kiprensky: His Life and Work" by Irina Shuvalova, "The Russian Academy of Arts in the First Half of the 19th Century" by Irina Pruzhan.

explanation: Giuliano da Maiano was born into a family of artisans, specifically stone masons, in the town of Maiano, near Fiesole. The family was not of noble lineage or extreme wealth, but they were skilled craftsmen, a profession that was respected and provided a decent living in the 15th century Italy. The family's craft would have provided Giuliano with access to education in the form of apprenticeship, which was common for children of artisans during this period. explanation: Carlo Marchionni was born in Rome around 1702. His father, Pietro Marchionni, was a stonemason, which would place the family within the middle class according to the specified typology. Stonemasonry was a skilled craft, and while it did not confer the wealth or prestige of the elite class, it would have provided a stable income and a level of social standing above the subsistence class. As a stonemason, Pietro Marchionni would have had the resources to provide his son with a basic education, which was likely how Carlo Marchionni was introduced to the principles of architecture. However, there is no evidence to suggest that the family was particularly wealthy or that they lived in anything other than modest circumstances.
sources: "Carlo Marchionni: A New Analysis of His Architecture" by Helena Szépe, "The Architecture of Rome" by Stefan Grundmann, "Rome: An Urban History from Antiquity to the Present" by Rabun Taylor, Katherine Rinne, Spiro Kostof.

explanation: Antonio Cavallucci was born in Sermoneta, Italy, in 1752. His father, Giuseppe Cavallucci, was a respected shoemaker, which indicates a skilled craft occupation typical of the middle class during this period. There is no evidence to suggest that the Cavallucci family was particularly wealthy or impoverished, but the fact that Antonio was able to study at the Accademia di San Luca in Rome suggests that his family had enough resources to support his education. This was not a privilege accessible to the subsistence class. The family's ability to send Antonio to Rome for his education also suggests that they were not living in conditions of extreme poverty. However, there is no evidence to suggest that the Cavallucci family was part of the elite ruling class or nobility.
sources: "Antonio Cavallucci: A New Source for His Biography and Artistic Training" by Stefano Grandesso, published in The Burlington Magazine (2005); "Antonio Cavallucci: His Life and Works" by Luigi Salerno, published in Storia dell'arte (1972).

explanation: Valentino Fioravanti was born in Rome, Italy, in 1764. His father, Domenico Fioravanti, was a professional musician, which suggests that the family belonged to the middle class. This is because, during the late 18th century in Italy, professional musicians were typically considered part of the middle class, as they were skilled artisans who could earn a living from their craft. There is no evidence to suggest that the Fioravanti family was particularly wealthy or impoverished, so it is reasonable to assume that they had a relatively stable, middle-class lifestyle. Valentino himself was able to receive a musical education from a young age, which further suggests that his family had the means to provide him with such opportunities. However, there is no evidence to suggest that he was born into the elite ruling class or the subsistence class.
sources: "Valentino Fioravanti: A Biographical Dictionary of Actors, Actresses, Musicians, Dancers, Managers, and Other Stage Personnel in London, 1660-1800" by Philip H. Highfill, Kalman A. Burnim, Edward A. Langhans.

explanation: Gioseffo Guami was born in Lucca, Italy, around 1542. sources: "Gioseffo Guami", Grove Music Online; "Music and Musicians in Renaissance Cities and Towns", Fiona Kisby (2001).

explanation: Cosimo Ridolfi was born into the Ridolfi family, one of the oldest and most prestigious noble families in Florence, Italy. explanation: Michelozzo di Bartolomeo Michelozzi was born in Florence, Italy, around 1396. Tailoring was a skilled craft, and while not as prestigious or wealthy as the merchant class, tailors were considered a step above laborers and peasants. There is no evidence to suggest that Michelozzo's family was particularly wealthy or impoverished, so it is reasonable to assume they were of average means for their social class. As for education, Michelozzo likely would have had access to basic education due to his family's middle-class status, but there is no evidence to suggest he received any formal education beyond that. His early life housing and living conditions would have been typical of the middle class in Florence at the time, likely a modest but comfortable home in the city. There is no evidence to suggest Michelozzo inherited any significant privileges or disadvantages due to his birth circumstances.

explanation: Giovanni Giustino Ciampini was born into a middle-class family in Rome, Italy. explanation: Marie Mancini was born into an aristocratic family. Her father, Baron Lorenzo Mancini, was a Roman aristocrat, while her mother, Geronima Mazzarini, was the sister of Cardinal Mazarin, the chief minister of France. This connection to the French court through her uncle would have given her a high social standing from birth. Her family was wealthy, and she would have had access to education and a comfortable living situation due to her family's status. However, her father died when she was young, and her mother took Marie and her sisters to live in France under the protection of their uncle, Cardinal Mazarin. Despite this, her birth and early childhood were marked by the privileges of the elite class.
sources: "The Mazarinettes: The Lives and Times of Seven Rich and Famous Sisters" by Richard A. Jackson; "The Cardinal's Niece: Marie Mancini" by Molly Caldwell Crosby.

explanation: Anton Menger was born in 1841 in Maniago, a town in the Kingdom of Lombardy-Venetia, which was then part of the Austrian Empire and is now in Italy. The family was of Jewish descent, which could have potentially limited their social mobility in the predominantly Catholic society of the time, but there's no evidence to suggest they lived in poverty. Anton Menger had access to education, as he attended the University of Vienna, which suggests that his family had the means to support his studies. However, this education was likely due to his family's financial resources rather than any inherited privilege. The family's living conditions are not well-documented, but as a cloth manufacturer, Jakob Menger would have likely been able to provide a comfortable home for his family.
sources:
- "Anton Menger and the Promise of Modernity," by Giandomenico Piluso, in the Journal of the History of Economic Thought.
- "Anton Menger: A Biographical Sketch," by Manfred Prisching, in the European Journal of the History of Economic Thought.

explanation: Cornelis de Wael was born into a family of artists, which suggests a middle-class background according to the provided typology. His father, Jan de Wael I, was a respected artist and his mother, Gertrude de Jode, came from a family of engravers and publishers. This indicates that the family had a certain level of wealth and social standing, but they were not part of the ruling class or nobility. The family's artistic background also suggests that Cornelis would have had access to education and training in the arts from a young age. The de Waels were originally from Antwerp, but they moved to Genoa, Italy, due to religious persecution. This suggests that they had the means to relocate, but also that they faced certain disadvantages due to their Protestant faith in a predominantly Catholic region.
sources: "Cornelis de Wael: A Flemish Painter in Rome," by Joaneath Spicer in The Art Bulletin, Vol. 66, No. 4 (Dec., 1984), pp. 609-623; "The de Wael Family and the Antwerp-Genoa Connection," by Nico Van Hout in The Burlington Magazine, Vol. 139, No. 1136 (Nov., 1997), pp. 724-731.

explanation:
Michelangelo Buonarroti was born on March 6, 1475, in the small village of Caprese, near Arezzo, in Tuscany, not 1568. His father, Lodovico di Leonardo di Buonarroti di Simoni, was the local magistrate in Caprese and Chiusi. Although the Buonarroti family was of minor nobility, they were not wealthy, and Michelangelo's father struggled to maintain his status. Michelangelo's mother, Francesca di Neri del Miniato di Siena, came from a middle-class background. 

Michelangelo was the second of five sons in the family. His mother's death when he was six affected the family's living conditions, and he was sent to live with a stonecutter's family, where he was exposed to the art of stone carving. This early exposure to the arts was not due to the family's wealth or status but rather a result of circumstances.

Despite his family's financial struggles, Michelangelo was able to receive an education due to his father's position. He was initially sent to study grammar with the humanist Francesco da Urbino in Florence, but he showed no interest in his schooling, preferring to copy paintings from churches and seek the company of painters.
sources: - Vasari, Giorgio. "The Lives of the Most Excellent Painters, Sculptors, and Architects." 1550
